abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Auditory neuropathy (AN) is a unique type of language developmental disorder, with no precise rate of genetic contribution that has been deciphered in a large cohort. In a retrospective cohort of 311 patients with AN, pathogenic and likely pathogenic variants of 23 genes were identified in 98 patients (31.5% in 311 patients), and 14 genes were mutated in two or more patients. Among subgroups of patients with AN, the prevalence of pathogenic and likely pathogenic variants was 54.4% and 56.2% in trios and families, while 22.9% in the cases with proband-only; 45.7% and 25.6% in the infant and non-infant group; and 33.7% and 0% in the bilateral and unilateral AN cases. Most of the <jats:italic>OTOF</jats:italic> gene (96.6%, 28/29) could only be identified in the infant group, while the <jats:italic>AIFM1</jats:italic> gene could only be identified in the non-infant group; other genes such as <jats:italic>ATP1A3</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>OPA1</jats:italic> were identified in both infant and non-infant groups. In conclusion, genes distribution of AN, with the most common genes being <jats:italic>OTOF</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>AIFM1</jats:italic>, is totally different from other sensorineural hearing loss. The subgroups with different onset ages showed different genetic spectrums, so did bilateral and unilateral groups and sporadic and familial or trio groups.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Committee of Medical Ethics of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) General Hospital (No. S2020-228-01), conforming to the Helsinki Declaration of Human and Animal Rights. Written informed consents from all the participants or their guardians were obtained.
